text:
Obviously the "find bet" -> ""place bet" turnaround time can be critical if you're taking current prices but that's generally a race against faster players. Personally, I compare servers and use the fastest one but don't optimise beyond that.
About 12 years ago, I was invited to beta test a VPS provider in Australia and was getting 6ms response times. Sadly, they didn't continue with the business.

elements.text:
Obviously the "find bet" -> ""place bet" turnaround time can be critical if you're taking current prices but that's generally a race against faster players. Personally, I compare servers and use the fastest one but don't optimise beyond that.
About 12 years ago, I was invited to beta test a VPS provider in Australia and was getting 6ms response times. Sadly, they didn't continue with the business.

text: My general view is to never have a strategy that relies on you being the fastest - because that is a tenuous proposition at best. I know in-play horse racing is a very different market than pre-play, but my former client made huge amounts on UK racing (possibly more than anyone else) and their strategy was to rely on probabilities that were generated some hours in advance and just betting late (in terms of minutes, not seconds)

elements.text: My general view is to never have a strategy that relies on you being the fastest - because that is a tenuous proposition at best. text: Just to repeat - yes, in-play betting on horse racing using GPS tracking is a very different market :wink:

elements.text: Just to repeat - yes, in-play betting on horse racing using GPS tracking is a very different market

text: Hi Misha,regarding your client who made huge amounts, how consistent were they? Did they tend to make money every day, week, month etc? I'm just wondering how accurate the anecdote is, that scalable stuff is less consistent.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Hi Misha,regarding your client who made huge amounts, how consistent were they? Did they tend to make money every day, week, month etc? I'm just wondering how accurate the anecdote is, that scalable stuff is less consistent.

text: On a monthly basis they made money - not sure they had a losing month. But over a couple of years, one or two months were close to zero. Many losing weeks. There was an inexorable trajectory upwards

elements.text: On a monthly basis they made money - not sure they had a losing month. But over a couple of years, one or two months were close to zero. Many losing weeks. There was an inexorable trajectory upwards

text: In terms of consistency, their model was brilliant, and consistently so. In theory it's simple - get better probabilities than the market, and when you bet, bet as big as you can (in multiple chunks). UK racing has very high liquidity, so works well for UK racing

elements.text: In terms of consistency, their model was brilliant, and consistently so. In theory it's simple - get better probabilities than the market, and when you bet, bet as big as you can (in multiple chunks). UK racing has very high liquidity, so works well for UK racing

text: There are different styles. Broadly: If you're heavily reliant on 'news' - as in new information being incorporated into the market then you're also likely to need to be fastest both in getting the news and acting on it because that's a straight up race. If you're more dependent on analysis - taking information that everyone already has and stitching it together in some novel way then speed is likely to be less important.

elements.text: There are different styles. text: Personally I'm not obsessed with speed but that's partly because it's not my skill-set. You have to fight the battles you can win. That said; there's no reason to want to be slow. Sometimes there are reasons to delay executing transactions but you want to be doing that out of choice when it's appropriate.

elements.text: Personally I'm not obsessed with speed but that's partly because it's not my skill-set. You have to fight the battles you can win. That said; there's no reason to want to be slow. Sometimes there are reasons to delay executing transactions but you want to be doing that out of choice when it's appropriate.

text: I think that anyone who is relying on speed as the major factor  in their strategy is on a long and tortuous road these days, especially if you are offering money to the market. (not to say that it hasn't worked in the past). There is no point being first to a party only to find that there is no one else to talk to....and just as you leave, someone else turns up. You could for example still get there first, but wait around a little longer..or any other combination

text: Yeah, in the early days of API 6. It was Betfair support (probably Neil) that put me in touch with the VPS provider as they'd contacted Betfair asking for testers. Didn't really do much with the super fast connection at the time as liquidity was always poor on the Aus markets.

text: Totally agree with <@UQL0QDEKA>, speed reliant strategies are hard to master because competition is fierce. We all know that laying the field at 1.01 is profitable IF your bets are at the front of the queue, but getting to the front of the queue is like challenging Bolt to a sprint after you've had 10 pints and a kebab.
